awd_titl_txt: Scatterings, Reactions and Quantum Many-Body States in Ultracold Molecules
awd_abstract_narration:
Modern quantum techniques have allowed scientists to prepare molecules in their ground states and cool these molecules down to a temperature regime of a few tens of nanokelvin. Such ultracold molecules offer scientists unprecedented opportunities to explore a vast range of quantum phenomena unattainable before. Ultracold molecules could form new quantum matter that has no counterparts in other systems, give rise to a new platform for studying quantum chemistry, and potentially serve as a new powerful apparatus to implement quantum information processing. In all of these studies, a fundamental issue is to understand scatterings between molecules and how such scatterings determine the chemical reactions and the formation of novel quantum phases.  Addressing this issue is the goal of this project.  

This research will explore scatterings between molecules and study how these scatterings lead to quantum entanglement between different degrees of freedom and consequently the rise of novel topological quantum matter. The group will further implement the scatterings as a unique tool to manipulate two-body decays and will explore new universal relations for molecules with losses, which are inaccessible in closed systems. These universal relations will allow the team to trace both the reaction rate and many-body correlations using contacts, the central quantity in dilute quantum systems. The outcome of this project will deliver new tools to control losses of ultracold molecules and provide guidance for experimentalists to search for novel superfluids and other quantum many-body phases. Furthermore, it could bring the research of contacts and universal relations to a new domain of open quantum systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Ultracold molecules have emerged as a highly controllable platform for physicists to explore fundamental questions in few-body and many-body physics. Compared to other quantum systems, molecules exhibit some unique features. The two-body interactions between molecules are often inelastic, such that losses are common features of molecular systems. The molecular interactions are also highly controllable by adding external fields to dress their internal states. These unique features provide physicists with exciting new opportunities to obtain new quantum states and, at the same time, grand challenges to understand the losses in a quantum many-body environment.

We have found that two-body losses in molecules confined in one- or two-dimensional traps are intrinsically related to many-body correlations through universal relations established via contacts. Compared to their counterparts in three dimensions, these universal relations have unique features due to the lower dimensionality and provide physicists with a new framework to explore the interplay between losses and confinement. We have also unfolded some black hole physics hidden in lossy molecules with a unit probability of reaction, where the one-way traffic in the scattering of such molecules mimics the propagation of matter waves outside the event horizon of a black hole.

We have found that tunable interactions between molecules provide physicists with a natural platform to access new quantum many-body states. When the interaction becomes long-range, constrained kinetics may appear in the Hamiltonians. An unconventional type of condensates made of dipoles then arise and couple to gauge fields in an unusual manner, as they are resistant to ordinary vector gauge fields. We have worked out schemes to prepare such dipole condensates in laboratories and investigated new macroscopic quantum phenomena induced by their couplings to higher-rank tensor gauge fields. Another example is a new class of spin models that could flip two spins in the same direction, such that chiral solitons can be generated.

The outcome of this project provides a new theoretical perspective to understand lossy molecules at low temperatures and in lower dimensions, where quantum many-body correlations and confinement intrinsically affect losses. The results about many-body states of molecules suggest a new direction to study exotic phases of interdisciplinary interest, such as the fractonic phase of matter and chiral solitons. This project has been used to train graduate students and young researchers to learn fundamental knowledge and advanced topics in multiple subareas of physics, including AMO physics, cosmology, and condensed matter physics.
